title: Super League XX
text:
The 2015 Super League season, known as the <a href="First%20Utility">First Utility</a> Super League XX for sponsorship reasons, was the 20th <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> season since the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> was introduced in 1996. Twelve teams competed over 23 rounds, including the <a href="Magic%20Weekend">Magic Weekend</a>, after which the eight highest entered the play-offs for a place in the <a href="2015%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">Grand Final</a>. The four lowest teams entered the Super League Qualifying Play-off, along with the four highest <a href="Championship%20%28rugby%20league%29">Championship</a> teams, to decide which will play in <a href="Super%20League%20XXI">Super League XXI</a>. The regular season started in February 2015 and culminated with the <a href="2015%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">grand final</a> on 10 October.
<a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds Rhinos</a> became only the 3rd team to complete the treble after defeating <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan Warriors</a> 22-20 in front of a new record attendance of 73,512 at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a> to win their 7th <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> title.
Teams.
Super League XX is the first year since 2008 in which there is a promotion and relegation with the Championship. Super League has been reduced to 12 teams as part of the re-structuring of Super League and the <a href="Championship%20%28rugby%20league%29">Championship</a>.
Eleven teams in Super League are from the North of England: five teams, <a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a>, <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a>, <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a>, <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a> and <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a>, west of <a href="the%20Pennines">the Pennines</a> in the historic county of Lancashire and six teams, <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a>, <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a>, <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a>, <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a>, <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> and <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>, to the east in Yorkshire. <a href="Catalans%20Dragons">Catalans Dragons</a>, in <a href="Perpignan">Perpignan</a>, France, are the only team outside the North of England. With <a href="Bradford%20Bulls">Bradford Bulls</a> and <a href="London%20Broncos">London Broncos</a> being relegated last season, this leaves St Helens, Wigan Warriors, Warrington Wolves and Leeds Rhinos as the only teams to have played in every season of Super League since 1996.
Standings.
Regular season.
The 2015 Super League season sees teams play each other home and away, and one team for a third time at the <a href="Magic%20Weekend">Magic Weekend</a>. After 23 games, the league table is frozen and the teams are split up into "Super 8's". Teams finishing in the top 8 will play 7 more games each as they compete in the Super League Super 8 group for a place in the Grand Final. Teams finishing in the bottom four will join the top 4 teams from the Championship in The Qualifiers Super 8 group and also play 7 more games each for a place in the 2016 Super League competition.
Super 8s.
The Super League Super 8's sees the top 8 teams from the Super League play 7 games each. Each team's points are carried over and after 7 additional games the top 4 teams will contest the play off semi-finals with the team in 1st hosting the team in 4th, and the team finishing 2nd hosting the 3rd placed team; the winners of these semi-finals will contest the Super League Grand Final at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a>. 
Teams finishing 5th, 6th, 7th and 8th after the 7 additional games will take no further part in the 2015 season but will play in Super League again in 2016.
The Qualifiers Super 8's sees the bottom 4 teams from Super League table join the top 4 teams from the Championship. The points totals are reset to 0 and each team plays 7 games each, playing every other team once. After 7 games each the teams finishing 1st, 2nd, and 3rd will gain qualification to the 2016 Super League season. The teams finishing 4th and 5th will play in the "Million Pound Game" at the home of the 4th place team which will earn the winner a place in the 2016 Super League; the loser, along with teams finishing 6th, 7th and 8th, will be relegated to the Championship.
End-of-season awards.
Awards are presented for outstanding contributions and efforts to players and clubs in the week leading up to the Super League Grand Final:
Media.
Television.
2015 is the fourth year of a five-year contract with Sky Sports to televise 70 matches per season. The deal which runs until 2016 is worth £90million.
<a href="Sky%20Sports">Sky Sports</a> coverage in the UK will see two live matches broadcast each week, usually at 8:00 pm on Thursday and Friday nights.
Regular commentators will be <a href="Eddie%20Hemmings%20%28rugby%20league%29">Eddie Hemmings</a> and <a href="Mike%20Stephenson">Mike Stephenson</a> with summarisers including <a href="Phil%20Clarke">Phil Clarke</a>, <a href="Brian%20Carney%20%28rugby%29">Brian Carney</a>, <a href="Barrie%20McDermott">Barrie McDermott</a> and <a href="Terry%20O%27Connor%20%28rugby%20league%29">Terry O'Connor</a>. Sky will broadcast highlights on Sunday nights on "Super League - Full Time" at 10 p.m.
<a href="BBC%20Sport">BBC Sport</a> will broadcast a highlights programme called the "<a href="Super%20League%20Show">Super League Show</a>", presented by Tanya Arnold. The BBC show two weekly broadcasts of the programme, the first to the <a href="BBC%20North%20West">BBC North West</a>, <a href="BBC%20Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a>, <a href="BBC%20North%20East%20and%20Cumbria">North East and Cumbria</a>, and <a href="BBC%20Yorkshire%20and%20Lincolnshire">East Yorkshire and Lincolnshire</a> regions on Monday evenings at 11:35 p.m. on <a href="BBC%20One">BBC One</a>, while a repeat showing is shown nationally on <a href="BBC%20Two">BBC Two</a> on Tuesday afternoons at 1.30 p.m. The "Super League Show" is also available for one week after broadcast for streaming or download via the <a href="BBC%20iPlayer">BBC iPlayer</a> in the UK only. End of season play-offs are shown on BBC Two across the whole country in a weekly highlights package on Sunday afternoons.
Internationally, Super League is shown live or delayed on <a href="ShowSports">Showtime Sports</a> (Middle East), <a href="Sky%20Sport%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Sky Sport</a> (New Zealand), <a href="TV%202%20Sport%20%28Norway%29">TV 2 Sport</a> (Norway), <a href="Fox%20Soccer%20Plus">Fox Soccer Plus</a> (United States), <a href="Fox%20Sports%20%28Australia%29">Fox Sports</a> (Australia) and <a href="Sportsnet%20World">Sportsnet World</a> (Canada).
